title: Vintage Fast Food Chains
description: Test your memory of the fast food restaurants that shaped American dining from the 1940s through the 1980s!

questions.question: Which fast food chain, founded in 1940 by brothers Richard and Maurice, originally started as a barbecue restaurant in San Bernardino, California?
questions.explanation: McDonald's was founded by the McDonald brothers in 1940 as a barbecue restaurant before being transformed into a hamburger stand in 1948.

questions.question: What was the original name of Burger King when it opened in 1953?
questions.explanation: Burger King was originally called Insta-Burger King when it opened in Jacksonville, Florida in 1953. It was renamed Burger King in 1959.

questions.question: Which fast food chain introduced the first modern drive-through window in 1975?
questions.explanation: Wendy's is credited with introducing the first modern drive-through window in 1975 at their location in Oklahoma City.

questions.question: Howard Johnson's restaurants were famous for offering how many flavors of ice cream?
questions.explanation: Howard Johnson's was famous for its 28 flavors of ice cream, which helped make it the largest restaurant chain in America during the 1960s.

questions.question: Which fast food restaurant chain used the slogan 'Where's the beef?' in a famous 1984 TV commercial?
questions.explanation: Wendy's aired the iconic 'Where's the beef?' commercial in 1984 featuring Clara Peller. The phrase became a national catchphrase.

questions.question: What was the name of the mascot for the Big Boy restaurant chain?
questions.explanation: Bob's Big Boy featured a chubby boy mascot in checkered overalls holding a large hamburger. The character was created in 1936 by Bob Wian.

questions.question: Which fried chicken chain was founded by a 65-year-old Harland Sanders using his $105 Social Security check?
questions.explanation: Colonel Harland Sanders used his first Social Security check to help fund his Kentucky Fried Chicken franchise business in 1952, at age 65.

questions.question: What was the name of the drive-in restaurant chain famous for carhops on roller skates?
questions.explanation: Sonic Drive-In, founded in 1953 in Shawnee, Oklahoma, became famous for its carhops who delivered food to your car, often on roller skates.

questions.question: Which pizza chain was the first to offer home delivery, starting in 1960?
questions.explanation: Domino's Pizza, founded in 1960, pioneered the pizza delivery model and built their entire brand around fast home delivery.

questions.question: What did McDonald's famously sell its hamburgers for when it first opened with its Speedee Service System?
questions.explanation: McDonald's sold their hamburgers for 15 cents when they launched the Speedee Service System in 1948, offering fast, affordable food.

questions.question: Which fast food chain introduced the concept of a 'value meal' combining a burger, fries, and drink in the 1960s?
questions.explanation: McDonald's pioneered the value meal concept in the 1960s, bundling a burger, fries, and drink together at a discounted price.

questions.question: What was the name of the root beer stand chain founded in 1919 that became one of America's first franchise restaurants?
questions.explanation: A&W Root Beer was founded in 1919 by Roy Allen and Frank Wright. It became one of America's first franchise restaurant chains in 1925.

questions.question: Which taco chain was founded by Glen Bell in 1962 in Downey, California?
questions.explanation: Taco Bell was founded by Glen Bell in 1962. Bell had previously operated a hot dog stand and several Mexican food restaurants before launching the chain.

questions.question: What was the signature item at White Castle, one of America's oldest fast food chains founded in 1921?
questions.explanation: White Castle, founded in 1921 in Wichita, Kansas, was famous for its small, square hamburgers nicknamed 'sliders' that were steam-grilled on a bed of onions.

questions.question: Which restaurant chain was known for its orange-roofed buildings and became the largest food chain in America in the 1960s and early 1970s?
questions.explanation: Howard Johnson's, with its distinctive orange roof and weathervane, was the largest restaurant chain in America during the 1960s with over 1,000 locations.
